author: chrissorem
content:
Story time:  yesterday I received a text from a manager I supposedly know. He Said I have an artist that has a jazz album that needs mixed. He asked me can you text him? I thought to myself that’s not normally how this goes but sure..  so I texted and within an instant, he called me. He said.” did you look me up?” I said no I just texted you like I was asked. He said.” you should look me up.” he proceeded to tell me  he’s been signed to major label  for 25 years. Supposedly Warner brothers and followed with they gave him $600 to mix this album which then I said I’m sorry but I can’t help you.. he said “send me a number of someone who can mix a jazz album.” I sent him to a friend who I know it was hurting for work.. then he text me back about five minutes later and said this guy never mixed a jazz album before. Send me  somebody who mixed a jazz album preferably over 40. I sent him Al Schmitt’s contact and he responded to me. “All has  been dead for several years get with it man.”

there’s nothing to be learned here.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
...completely unrelated to anything  but on my mind this morning

Something I've said here (maybe too) often is that approaching the work in a loving way is a real unlock. Love being a quaity of a attention, a way of meeting things. It might not be obvious but it can start small and grow out embracing many more aspects of what we do

I mastered an album a few months back for a phenomenal indie artist, @Rob Domos and I both absolutely loved the music and the overall experience. The artist's team came back this week with a last minute request to remaster what was probably my favorite track with an added feature from a legacy artist. It's kind of mind bending how much better it is

Rob and I spent some time yesterday just appreciating that someone (the artist, manager, A&R?) actually thought up the idea of this feature and made it happen. I was so content with what it was but someone somewhere was like *"you know what would be sick ..."* and made it real. And now the world gets to receive something beyond what we could have imagined, something we didn't even know we needed

Just focussing our attention on that for 2 mins in the hall yesterday made the day better and put some gas in the tank. There are so many challenges in what we do, it really helps to take time to focus attention on the jewels strewn everywhere too. They are not always immediately obvious

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, early in working with Cavallo we we’re doing a project at Skywalker Ranch in Nor Cal, living there for about 6 weeks. And he would unwind by cooking the staff these huge dinners in the industrial kitchen and then when they all retired for the night he would crack a bottle of wine and just talk shop with me for an hour or two. One night we’re talking about mixers, and I mentioned doing a project with another producer where one of the big big big name mixers had tanked the record. And he said “well whose fault is that?” And I responded the mixers obviously, it was awesome when we sent it to him. And he said “no, with all due respect, it’s the producer’s job. I sent back *grammy winning record here* 12 times to that mixer because the mix was just not quite right. As a producer your only job at the end of the day is ‘can i stand behind this record, is this the best the artist could possibly put out. Does it rule’. THAT is the job of a producer. A guy like Fields might get there by re playing all the instruments when the band leaves. A guy like Rubin might give them a reading assignment. They’re both equally producers because at the end of the day their records are consistently quality, however they get there. THAT is the job. The rest is just details”

The people that know how will always work for the people that know why. 

That lesson was invaluable to me.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
📖 story time:

Arguably one of the most important things I did in my career was a last minute instrumental version of "I Love Rock N Roll" for an A&R at Syco in the US for some random contestant on the short-lived US version of the X Factor. I crushed it on a deadline, then that same A&R hired me a year later to work on a band called Emblem 3 who was on X Factor US as well. I crushed that and then six months after that he recommended me to a UK A&R who was having trouble finishing a song for One Direction. I did a spec production on the song Best Song Ever and they liked it and used it and all of a sudden I become a big pop producer. Stemming from doing an great job on some instrumental cover for a dumb singing tv show.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Hey folks, back from mix with the masters with Jon & Teezio. I wanted to share just a little bit in case anyone else here is considering attending a workshop in the future. I was initially on the fence, but am very glad I went. 

Jon & Teezio were amazing together. I don't know how often MWTM does workshops with two engineers, but it really enriched the experience for me. It was actually comical how different their perspectives were on mixing, the business side, motivation for the work, lifestyle, etc... This created fascinating debate / conversation in the group. The Grammy nominations were announced while we were all together and we got to celebrate Jon & Teezio as a group for their I think combined 6 or 7 nominations. They brought in a bucket of champaign. All this after having gone through the sessions for said grammy nominated work earlier in the week. 10 / 10.

Rue Boyer studios is actually insane. Probably the best room I've been in.

There were attendees from all over the world. We ended up sharing mixes and receiving feedback from J&T. Hearing and sharing records in the same room with the people who made them with context provided from varying countries, cultures, genres, and scenes was as enlightening a music listening experience as I'm likely to have for the rest of my life.

So if anyone else here is on the fence in the future. Here's a tiny nudge.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
We all want our work to be undeniable, but the only way for most of us to get there is to slog through it. 

The music industry has an uncanny ability to burn out the chaff- passing vanity and a belief that somehow you’re special is just not enough to keep you going in the dark times. And most of the times are dark, my friends. 

But the upshot is, most of the folks I came up with that stuck with it are doing really cool shit now. A lot of my heroes have become friends. I’ve done a lot of cool bucket list type shit. And truly it’s not cause I myself am undeniable, it’s cause I slogged through.

author: Slow Hand

You come home late one night and the real Serban is waiting for you in your darkened living room. He reveals the existence of the Mixer Illuminati and explains that he is but one of many people throughout history playing the role of Serban Ghenea; a mythical figure who has steered the course of art and commerce from the shadows for millenia.

Rome, Tenochtitlan, Mesopotamia. Serban was there. The fingerprints of past Serbans can be found throughout all major historical events - mostly just to dial back the presence of 3kHz where they can, but they were *there* nonetheless!

author: LAPhill
content:
To piggyback on @cian riordan 's point, there are real, tangible benefits to being quiet in the back of the room. I would love to be a fly on the wall while @BatMeckley is producing a chart-topping vocalist, or see how Cian works through a first pass of a mix for his next Grammy-winning client. I guarantee they've learned a thing or two about how to talk to sensitive, demanding, highly respected artists. And they've learned how to interpret vague feedback ("make the vocal less green")  and working with people who can't articulate what they want. These are things you can't learn by watching Youtube videos or going to school.

When I was an assistant at Remote Control, getting to sit in and see how Hans handles a note from Jerry Bruckheimer taught me more than years of music education. Watching my boss struggle for 6 months on a 10-minute cue and then sit in a meeting with grace and calm while he's being told to change everything he just spent many long nights working on. 

That's not to mention things like learning how the real pros handle file management, deliveries, deadlines, tech problems, etc.. There is so much beyond learning the gear that comes from being a good assistant. If Matt knows you're going to shut up AND have his back with lackluster cookies, he's going to let you hang in the room longer. Which means you can absorb and learn more. It's a win-win.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Got a call this week to save a track. Producer turned it in pretty half baked and didnt give the mixer any direction. The first time the artist heard it was first pass at mix, and he HATED it. 

Artist was SUPER uncomfortable about the whole thing, but didn’t trust the producer to get it done for a bunch of reasons. 

1) the producer rushed the vocal recording. Artists wanted more takes but basically got bullied out of the room. 
2) The artist wanted to be there for the comp at least, producer refused. As I said, first time he heard it was after first mix pass. 
3) producer baked some Sonics into the vocal that were very outside for the artist, and there were bad edits & poor Melodyne work to boot. 


Now not only is the mixer gonna have to mix the vocals all over again (we’re retracking,) but all the other shit I’m adding/changing. 

So this producer made the artist uncomfortable and then made more work for everyone, on a major label budget. 

I’m not gonna speculate on the why, but there are some lessons here.

author: cian riordan
content: In defense of Peter, he and I operate in a VERY different world of vocal production than Beckley (and even yourself) do – with different sonic expectations, priorities, and goals. Beckley was part of the gang that forged new ground in modern pop vocal production... he's built a big part of his career on it, so of course we should listen to his insight. author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve got a good one of these: a girl I worked with came by to record a feature on a DJ Duo’s song. We spend a day or two recording it, and it’s AMAZING. I bring by everyone I know by the studio to play it for them, because I KNOW it’s a hit, and i want to be the guy who called his shot. I’ve got points on it, and possibly even a piece of the publishing. 

A few months later my little brother calls me and says “hey, I just heard *artist B* singing that song you played me that had *artist A* on it.

That song became one of the most played songs of that year, now nearing 3.5 billion streams on Spotify alone. My cut would have easily been in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not breaking a million.

¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 

Sometimes the stuff we do pans out. Sometimes it doesn’t. We kick Cian in the ribs and we move on.

author: Slow Hand
content:
On reflection, the material benefits of *Option #1* are a nice selling point, but I think the bigger opportunity is to harness the superpower of rendering hit music at will. It would give me tremendous sway over the music industry once everyone comes to recognize that I can't miss. I would leverage that influence to make some positive changes where I can. Set up some institutions to cultivate and nurture the next generation of artists. 

Presumably, while the hit music I’m making runs counter to my personal tastes, it seems reasonable that it would still be valuable to *someone*. Just not to me. That will be my curse. I would dutifully churn out hits as fast as I am able to and gift humanity with a tsunami of unimpeachable pop awesomeness that will endure for a century. My sacrifice would be everyone else’s gain.

Counter-intuitively, by saturating the market with my personal brand of songwriting it would inspire the next generation of songwriters. Unable to compete with my torrent of sure-shot pop badness they would respond by writing new music that is the direct antithesis of my own brand of hits. With a little luck, the musical output of these writers would be exactly what I wished to hear all along.

That’s a win/win right there. I just have to suffer a bit. I choose *Option #1*.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
This is a great conversation and it’s super interesting to see how culture and geography influences it.

As a Brit, the class system very much underpins life, even now (but in much different, more complex ways), so I share some of @Deleted User’s sentiments as the game is often rigged against a large portion of the populace despite their best efforts to turn things around for themselves. If only we had pure meritocracy here. Sam Fender put it really well this week with regards to the music industry so I won’t go over stony ground, you can google his thoughts which I largely relate to.

As an individual I’m horribly determined and annoyingly persistent when I have a goal in mind, as well as always balancing that with being the kindest person I can be towards others (sometimes to my detriment) and pretty much always in a headspace of bettering myself personally and professionally. This has generally been the key to many of the opportunities I’ve been given. There’s an English word for it, “nous”, which I think is similar to agency but also encompasses the notion of having “good sense”. I quite like that as it’s less about intelligence, and more about personal character. Just my two cents. As always firing off quick thoughts in a session break so I’m sorry if my take is a bit disconnected.

author: spectrummasters
content:
This completely resonates with me. The business of music doesn’t sit as well with me as the business of construction. There’s a camaraderie and kinship in physical labour on construction projects, and an embodied intelligence in that world that offsets the subjective and (for me) atomised work of hours alone mixing.

When I’m doing construction work, I’m also free to think objectively and from a distance about my audio engineering work.

Most of all, something changes for me when I’m being paid for musical “work” that I’m not entirely happy with. I’ve discussed this privately with a few folks here, and it seems the relationship between music and its commodification is problematic for more than a few of us. Simply put, it’s sometimes less enjoyable — though equally amazing — being paid for a passion.

I couldn’t recommend a construction or skilled trade career enough. It’s incredibly flexible and offers a tonic to music careers: you know you can walk onto a site tomorrow and get paid quickly and well. It’s always going to be around, and in my case, the certifications allow me to consider migrating to most economies globally as a skilled worker.

Construction allows me to be my own patron for my musical endeavours, and that feels really good.

I’d love to see a bigger debate here about how working in the upper echelons of the music industry feels long term — challenges, payoffs, economics, job security, retirement, healthcare, family life versus work life, and a world where socialising is networking.

Construction is a simpler engagement: competency, find a solution, do the work, go home.

I came across @cian riordan discussing becoming a fireman on Conversations, and much of what you said, Cian, is exactly what I get from construction.

I love how for you, though — instead of the firehouse bell calling, it was multiple Grammys!

author: Slow Hand
content:
Now I'm curious. How do y'all normally use Spotify? I've got a few modes:

1. I know exactly what I want to hear. I search it and start listening.

2. If I'm less picky I choose an album from an artist and listen through it entirely.

3. I put my *Liked Songs* playlist (roughly 2k songs, anything goes) on shuffle and let it rip.

4. Thurs at 9p I listen to my *Release Radar* playlist for the new releases from artists I follow.

5. Monday morning I listen to my *Discover Weekly* playlist and listen to the 30 songs it's recommending me.

Those are the main ways that I engage with the app. Is anyone here doing something significantly different? Radio stations maybe? Specific playlists?

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
I moved here 2 years ago with a bunch of savings and making very little money in music. It took me about a year to pull in enough income from mixing and spotify streams where I could stop living off savings and only on music income. 

But, It IS so expensive to live here, and I like to do things. typical night out is like $80 after drinks and ubers. Gas is $80. An egg sandwich is $16 lol. The constant worrying of if i was going to make enough that month got to me, so of a couple months ago, I returned to a freelance software engineering gig 3 days a week. Never been happier. A _lot_ of people in LA are doing the same: _side hustles are your friend_ . 

Another thing i'd add is when you first move here, try to combine your studio and living expenses. Studio spots here start at like $1800 a month and go up from there. I live in a beautiful house in silverlake with roommates where I have a room, my own bathroom, _and my own studio_ in the furnished garage for $1300. Try to get something like that.

author: Slow Hand
content:
People who don't win Grammys will never be losers unless their goal was to compete and win a Grammy. Then they're losers by their own competitive standard, and losing is all part of the game.

Everyone else can only stand to gain by being nominated. The act of being nominated is a reward in it's own right. It's a net positive and validating moment for anybody's career. While it may be disappointing not to win, hopefully they'll never feel that they're losers for failing to win something that they didn't ask for.

This is all to say that it's a matter of mindset. If you're not actively trying to win a Grammy, then a loss shouldn't be construed as some demeaning thing and the nomination is still a net positive. I don't think it's on the Grammys to regulate people's emotional state.

author: Will Melones
content: It's worth keeping in mind that there are living tortoises that have been around longer than the 'music industry' we know. For all the centuries before that it was just a thing that regular people participated in. Wealthy people had pianos in their homes and many knew how to play them. There was no Elvis or Britney Spears. For a while music publishing was literally the printing of sheet music. So maybe it's more crazy to think that there was recently this blip in time when people valued music enough to pay money to own it on little circles and cram into an arena to watch somebody sing on a jumbotron. It sounds kinda like claiming ownership of the sky if you think of art that way.

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well, it's hard to say what's best without a more holistic understanding of who you are and your circumstances, so I’m reluctant to offer any hard suggestions. Making a career in the music industry is what engineers would call a "wicked" problem. It's not something that has a repeatable solution, and what works for someone rarely works the same way for the next person.

That said, I see that you’re from Boston. I lived there for seven years, and the talent pool in that city is tremendous. I think if you found yourself back home in Boston it would be a worthwhile investment to integrate yourself into the scene of young musicians that are centered around the schools in the Back Bay like Berklee, NEC, and Boston Conservatory. There are some immensely talented, diverse, and creative people from all around the world based at those institutions and they all exist within 8 blocks of each other. It’s rare to have such a concentration of driven musicians all mingling amongst each other. This is a massive resource that you can tap into. They're *all* trying to make something great and explore what's possible.

It's a unique opportunity to discover collaborators, build relationships, earn experience in your craft, and build strong connections for the future as you grow alongside these people. On top of that, Boston has numerous recording studios where you can intern and assist. There’s a lot of experience to be gained working in a studio that simply won’t be taught to you in a recording program. Supplement that practical experience with hard work, and some book learning and you can do very well for yourself.

There’s more that I’m not touching-on, but I think if you ended up back in Boston it not be as much as a trade-off as you may think.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
yup. brighter=better to a lot of A&Rs, so it makes sense that this is the default for a lot of people. i haven't found a mastering engineer i love since tom coyne (rip) for this exact reason. my mixes often come back brighter and it annoys me. 

i had my first mix mastered by Dale Becker recently and he made a great midrange adjustment and didn't touch the high end. obviously Jon talks about him a lot, so that co-sign plus my one experience will make me go to him more in the future. 

also, a good mastering engineer should take the note "i don't want it brighter." they're pros that want to do great work and be hired again. you're the client, so don't be shy about telling them.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Mmhm. At first glance the obvious move seems to be that Spotify could double its subscription rate to $20/month and kick a larger margin towards the artist. I think unlimited music is certainly worth that. Setting aside, for the moment, all of the other complexities around market pricing, we also need to remember that Spotify's largest streaming competitors are Apple and Amazon.

These are companies with massive war-chests derived from the success of their non-streaming companies. Even if Spotify *wanted* to raise the cost of their service, companies like Apple and Amazon can afford to keep the price of streaming services depressed and sustain a loss on their streaming services for far longer than Spotify ever could. To my eyes, Spotify doesn't have a whole lot of wiggle-room to adjust their pricing and therefore their payout models.

I say as much, because in casual discussions around streaming payouts, there doesn't seem to be much awareness of the larger business ecosystem that a company like Spotify finds itself in.

author: spectrummasters
content: Wellllll, as the person who asked the opening question , re: marketing and perceived value, it did seem to open up a broad discussion with a lot of varied input . Wherever it got into any perceived sense of entitlement , was off track as the core of the question was about leveraging and better pay/benefits for the successful elite (nothing to do with people striving to get there ) . It wasn’t a question about working hard.....or having talent......or how to share a pie and how much pie there is ......that’s all a given in the original discussion I referenced that was between two Grammy winning engineers.  It was a discussion about marketing and the idea of engineers  leveraging for more as a community looking forwards . One  platform was mentioned here earlier that I have experience with.......and they are definitely driving value down with their marketing.  Through the history of time workers have had to fight for more (pay/benefits/better working conditions / contracts ) and imho that’s a legitimate and beneficial force in society. Noam Chomsky describes a point at which society collapses is when the imbalance of the societal structure is such that the vast majority of the workforce can no longer afford to live . In the uk we are currently experiencing strikes across many services/industries. It’s not really my way to say if they are write or wrong ......but I think the concept of unionising and leveraging for “fairer/better :::::whatever you like “ is legitimate not entitled or moany  . The suffragettes did it ......I digress. I think IME it’s a fair observation that people employed on the business side of the music business in the big music companies in the  uk work with the expectation that this will result in take home regular pay, without fear of non-payment , working with full benefits re’ holiday pay , maternity pay , etc etc.......

author: Deleted User
content:
Spotify was not even supposed to be a paid service… their model and vision was never having to pay for music again; and letting THAT be high quality experience as if you are playing records you bought. They did indeed do that, and I don’t think it will go back. 

It was decentralization they were after. the record industry was already beyond rescue (to go back to its heyday) so they wanted a better piratesbay where people can hear the music right away, and not the messed up mp3 that has been converted to different codecs multiple times. The platforms opening up to everybody is why someone like myself or my clients can upload any kind of music. 

I mention all of this to say… I think that’s what they wanted. But I think they were hoping more people would use the free version so they can juice more profit out of the ads. I don’t think they were expecting this many people to go premium, which lowers the value of each ads… (because they won’t be listened to as much)

That fracturing is also why you can watch a movie on HBO one month and then it leaves HBO and becomes exclusive to Netflix a few months later.

It would be frustrating to sign up for Spotify cause you love Led Zeppelin only to find that they've re-licensed with Tidal a few months later.

author: baileybonds
content: Sounds like they want Sound Recording asset id’s, this is one of YTs asset types that are created when delivering audio fingerprint to YT Content ID. Worth asking to clarify tho, as there are numerous different asset types in YT CMS. He should be able to get a list of the asset IDs associated with his content from his distributor, in this case TuneCore. I do believe that Tunecore up charges for YT Content ID delivery but if he’s willing to pay them to deliver his audio fingerprints to YT CID, there should be no need to switch his back catalog to another distributor.

author: cian riordan
content: A big reason I like the Grace M905 grabbing my computer output digitally as well as the output of my PT converters digitally. That way, things are showing up at 0dBFS from both sources, while also feeding my metering through the same path (Clarity M + spectrum analyzer). With Spotify you need normalization off and volume at full — ideally you’d have Tidal and force control over the DAC and bypass core audio, but I’ve got no gripes with Spotify at this moment.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Two years ago I was experiencing AI slop on Spotify. Not often, but occasional records that made me stop and say "what the hell is this shit?" 

But, the thing I encountered the most were songs recommended to me that were low-effort songs attributed to well known artists (Billie Eilish, Nick Hakim, etc). These were clearly plays to imitate big artists and siphon off some streams from them for profit.

I'm happy to report that I haven't seen *anything* like this in over a year. Spotify seems to have successfully clamped down on this, in my experience. In fact, I'd forgotten about them completely until you mentioned the possibility of AI music on Spotify just now. The only AI music I encounter is "deliberate" AI artists like Obscurest Vinyl, who I follow.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m pretty sure Spotify main normalization is set to -14 LUFS. 

In my experience with Broadcast, streaming, Advertisement audio, the LUFS standards have proven incredibly useful and quite reliable. Every project to do for “web” is mastered to -14LUFS, North American broadcast is -24, and Euro -23. Hulu, Roku, YouTube, etc all have their own little specifications for loudness. 

LUFS takes into account perceived loudness whereas RMS does not. It also does not measure or add to the loudness for passages of audio that fall below a certain level of loudness. So if something is far quieter, it doesn’t get factored into the average loudness.

author: Slow Hand
content:
When did Spotify start defaulting to the "clean" version of tracks? I'm listening to this Baby Keem/Kendrick track right now and it's ruining it for me.

I recently re-listened to 'Blacks Reconstruction' by The Roots and it's completely unlistenable now that it has a good 80 edits in it, despite being labeled as the "Album Version": https://open.spotify.com/track/6cq1D3ZaL8SrrHkgHB8nwl?si=6720c9125a9e40b8

It's not as if records like this ever stood a chance of pop appeal and required an edited version to reach an audience. It's so dense with profanity that it'll never be played in public anyway. Now because of this censorship not only does it fail at being acceptable to a broad audience it's also rendered unlistenable to it's intended mature audience.

If I didn't already love this record and didn't already own an uncensored copy I almost certainly would never give it a fair listen and come to appreciate it. I can't help but wonder if a lot of great music today is being rejected out of hand and not discovered by new listeners because of the censorship.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
There also, in casual discussions around streaming payouts, does not seem to be much of an understanding of how the value of a stream is derived and the affect of choices made by non-music interests on that derivation.

Choices such as using a pro-rata payout model vs a user centric payout model. Spotify has said they would adopt a user centric model if the general music community called for it. This would probably be better for most of us.

Or even nuance surrounding what the definition of a stream is and consideration for the type of record being streamed relative to the payout amount. A stream of a record of complete silence is worth the same as a stream of the largest scale commercial release.

author: Slow Hand
content:
In this instance it seems like the label's employees and artist would be aligned on voting in a way that wins their artist a Grammy, and that seems to be your point. But I don't think it matters quite so much.

If you want to get all game theory about it, there are other competing labels with voting members and artists of their own who are *also* pushing to attain a Grammy, come voting season. So I think your thesis that a label might try to increase their odds of winning by directing their employees to vote for *their* artist is counter-balanced somewhat by their label competitors probably doing the same.

The net result in this scenario would be that the gap between major-labels winning and indie artists winning is widened.

But to your point regarding leverage, I can’t deny that leverage is important and being good is the best leverage. 

But I think that’s beyond what we’re talking about. Especially in  songwriting land, there are plenty of people who wrote hits that weren’t compensated accordingly. 

Restaurant business sucks, but if you’re good- you can make profits. Each neighborhoods have profit making restaurants. But when it comes to music industry, the proportion of those who actually make money is way low compared to restaurant business. In restaurant business, you still pay the workers regardless. You have to. In music, if the artist isn’t making money then the ones who get hired by artists have no chance of making money

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I enjoyed getting caught up on this thread from the past two days. In case anyone is interested there's a book that @shaunobi shared about previously here called '*Chokepoint Capitalism*' that I believe provides an interesting context for some of the topics / ideas from this convo. I'm about halfway through it myself.

There has been a lot of talk here about there not being enough money entering into the top of the music industry, but far less talk about how little of the money that does flows towards the artists and producers of the art that drives the industry and culture.

The book makes a pretty compelling case that copyright law, antitrust law / enforcement (or lack thereof), regulatory capture, the consolidation of power in the music industry and formation of monopolies / monopsonies with anticompetitive flywheels has greatly contributed to the reality or perception by some that the average creative worker in this industry is getting less in return for the actual value they are putting in. I'm still sifting through it but do think it's worth a read / would make for an interesting addition to the discussion.

author: Will Melones
content:
I guess it depends heavily on scale. $40 a month just to keep the doors open sounds steep for an artist who isn't already selling merch at a consistent rate. I haven't looked at Shopify's print on demand pricing, but in general POD is much higher cost than bulk screen printing t-shirts (for example). So if you're a band selling at the scale where $40/mo. on a slow month isn't your *entire* profit margin, it seems like investing in a run of merch would pay for itself.

Now this is completely different if you look at it from the perspective of a clothing brand, where the goal is to have a diversity of designs available at all times, without the need for warehousing and a huge startup cost, and to consistently push sales to a customer base that's devoted to *the merch*. I can't imagine the vast majority of DistroKid artists are going that hard on ecommerce, but they could sure benefit from having their POD merch visible on their Spotify profile. The small artists I work with would probably be better off putting $40 into Instagram ads every month.

Does anyone here host their personal music collection in the cloud? I've got a massive collection that could get more love, so I figure I should look into a solution for engaging with it more often.

2) The ability to organize and catalog everything meticulously.
3) A desktop and phone app that will allow me to stream any of it at will. Like using Spotify on your phone.
4) Requires very little in the way of ongoing subscription costs.

Does anyone know of any options that satisfy most of those needs?

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Question for the group: 
I have a few artist friends who have both been told by different music industry folks to consider starting fresh under new names. Their rationale seems to be that labels and other potential team members (booking agents, managers, etc...) want to hop on the fresh new promising HOT artist stonk :stonks:  rather than work with an artist who has been consistently releasing music for years but whose catalogue on streaming platforms is dominated or overrepresented by older works. That they are turned off by middling success after many attempts over time.

Would a truly amazing *undeniable* record have a better shot at commercial success under a new artist name with no previous middling successful tracks or nah? At what point, if ever, would it be beneficial for an artist to kill an artist project and start fresh under a new name with new music?

author: AJ
content:
Today someone asked about releasing a full album on an artist website as a digital product. The caveat is that singles are released once a month for streaming (full thing on streaming platforms at the end of the year, so the example had 12 singles).  After seeing some good discussion about the idea, I'm curious as to what y'all think about it? 

The main points I've heard in favor of the move:
- 1 person buying the album for 10 bucks cancels out so many no's
- Prioritizes real fans over casual listeners
- Incentivizes an artist to make the album, because it's batching content for a year. 
- Forces the artist to view music as a business, but doesn't fully leave the Spotify ecosystem.

Not sure where best to ask this, so I'll ask here:

What's the best way (or what are y'all doing) to make Spotify play back at the same level as your daw? 

I'm using an apollo for everything and I'd love to A/B things from a streaming service as I'm working on PT or Ableton. 

Spotify says turning its default to "loud" volume can compromise the sound quality, though I couldn't immediately find out what that means.

Will another streaming service do it? Do I need some extra interface or software? Why isn't this easy?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I keep my Spotify and Apple Music normalized, to live in the world most listeners do. And then Qobuz and Tidal are not normalized if a serious reference is required. Turning on and off in one app is likely to confuse IME

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Also remember that Spotify itself is a moving target - it can supply 3 different levels of normalization, 3 different file types (OGG/MP3/AAC) and multiple bit rates depending on settings/cellular bandwidth/mobile vs desktop vs embedded (car/smart tv)

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: From Tidal of course. With Spotify and Apple Music I’m only interested in having normalization on to inhabit the consumer’s world, as @Nomograph Mastering said above.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: If you print your mix to a final stereo track, I will change the input of that track from whatever master bus output , to “MON L/R “ - which is the direct feed output of the Apollo. Then I mute that track and hit play on Apple Music (normalization off!) to print. I just record reference tracks straight in as part of the playlists of final mixes, that way when I’m in input mode I’m listening to my mix, and when I take it out I hear the reference. Instant A/B

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But here’s the thing, and everyone should do this. Take a master, play in your DAW and then listen to it on Spotify

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
I find it really interesting that for instance in music streaming there are various streaming platforms that pretty much do exactly the same thing (provide all, or most of recorded music at a cost). There might be slight discrepancies (spotify not having Joni Mitchell/Neil Young catalogue until recently) but they offer essentially exactly the same product so they have to convince consumers from a different perspective („we pay artists more, we sound better, we have spatial audio etc.“) 
And on the other end of the spectrum you have the complete shitshow that is streaming movies/series on demand where you have to have like 5 different subscriptions bankrupting you just so you can watch your favourite movies. It‘s interesting how those two offer basically the same thing (access to entertainment on demand) but have developed drastically different

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I was recently inspired after going to the cinema to see *A Complete Unkown*, the movie memoir about Bob Dylan; partially by Bob's story, but also by Timothy Chalomee's performance as Bob. All of the shots of him performing in the movie were fully live - which is an impressive feat by itself - but even more impressive that he apparently wasn't much of a musician before making the movie. I didnt know much about Timothy before this, so I watched his interview with Zane Lowe on Apple Music's YouTube channel. One thing I found really interesting was how available he made himself to learning the role. For example, he didn't turn his phone on for 3 months straight. Got me thinking about how much I can get distracted during the day, and how these distractions can get in the way of me actually giving 100% to the art that I'm working on. I'm sure you all can imagine how the distractions in your own life can effect your work. Might be TikTok videos, might be discord, might be lusting over getting new converters or monitors or guitars, etc, you get the idea. So I guess what I'm saying here is that if I want to compete with the best, maybe I have to understand how to impliment systems in my life that allows me to be more available to the things that I am working on. I want it to be like lifiting a heavy weight at the gym - at the bottom of a heavy squat, you've no choice but to focus on pushing the bar back up with good form, cos that think will break you otherwise. There's a certain thing that happens in your brain when you're forced to only think about one thing for a prolonged, or even short period. It's something akin to meditating. 

I guess what I'm asking is if anyone has ever given this subject any thought before, and if anyone has ever done anything to get better at these things? I'm still not sure if all this only makes sense inside my own head.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think there’s a danger in assuming those that are successful didn’t have it hard.
2 quick stories that have shaped my career:

very early on when I was recruited to play in a band in Australia. Sold my car, got rid of my apartment, and flew out to Melbourne. Band had a moment but I got tossed out just as the song was going number 1. Had no money to get home, no where to stay, and was literally 23 living on our producers couch in a country about as far from home as possible. And I called my pop, basically telling him how bummed/scared/fucked I was. And he goes “you know, I just got off the phone with **** (a very famous actor friend of ours). If there’s anyone that had it all, you’d think it was him. Big career, wife on the cover of sports illustrated swimsuit edition, fans everywhere. But it turns out his Dad just passed, his wife is cheating on him, and if this new show doesn’t get picked up they might lose the house they just bought. EVERYONE has their share of crap they have to deal with, give or take, no matter how easy it looks from the outside. Life isn’t about what happens to you, it’s about how you deal with what happens to you. Figure out a way to make the most of what’s going on”. For some reason, knowing that EVERYONE’s life sucks to some degree, was immensely helpful in getting me back on my feet.

The other was a year or two later, when I started tuning vocals for Rob Cavallo. One of his wrecking crew of session musicians had been in a band with a huge hero of mine, who had sadly took his own life mid way through making his second record. I asked the guy if there was anything he could tell me about working with said hero, and he said “he was the best musician I’ve ever met. Whatever instrument you played he was better at it than you were within 10 minutes of picking it up. But he seemed to think he was the only guy that ever got a raw deal from the music industry”.

author: Will Trotman
content:
Interesting, that’s good to hear it’s gotten better, I was assuming it had gone the other way. 

I just wonder what kind of disruption could be large enough to cause a shift away from Spotify, since they’re pretty firmly on top. It seems like streaming is about as easy as it’s going to get, and I don’t really hear any Spotify users with qualms about their experience.

I do wonder if artists will become less partial to Spotify over time though. It seems like there are so many different metrics of success now (Spotify streams, instagram followers, tik tok followers are the main ones I think of) that aren’t always mutually inclusive of each other. And I wonder if that takes a little weight off of streaming numbers being the only metric that legitimizes an artist. And I hear people like Ryan Tedder talk about the importance of “world building” for artists now - I wonder if fans of artists will care more about being part of that artist’s ecosystem than the artist’s music being a part of their music library. I think of how K Pop bands sell crazy numbers of physical copies as an example. They can still stream the music but it seems like there are more variables now.

Thinking out loud a little bit, I might have just said absolutely nothing with a lot of words lol.

author: Will Trotman
content:
Has anyone here ever experienced a significant loss of fidelity (like more than normal) with tracks after they’re distributed? Been listening back to a project I did that came out end of last year and, after A/Bing the songs with the master files, I’m pretty positive something is going on. The artist double checked the files and they’re all the right ones. Only thing I can think of is they switched from distrokid to a different company mid project rollout. Not sure how that would affect things.

The sound is just kinda phasey, almost “bubbly.” Kinda like if someone threw a bunch of waves NS1 all over the session (which I didn’t lol). Kinda driving me a little crazy.

Edit: Got confirmation from the artist and ME that it’s weird. It’s only on the singles she uploaded to distrokid before switching to the smaller distro, so she’s reaching out to them. Beware the distro switch.
